page.title: 01Claonaig Estuary Kintyre
page.content: This unspoiled area adjoins the Claonaig Valley and is similarly farmed. Tehre are fewer confierous trees but it has a shoreline of scrub oak designated as a Site of Special Scientific Interest. The Claonaig Burn exists into the Kilbrannon Sound which covers 1/3 of the aea. A summer car ferry connects Kintyr with Arran. Sea Fishing, once plentiful, is now poor. Salmon and seatrout are netted off the Burn mouth. Numbers of Roe deer nd Sika are increasing, as are foxes Badgers and otters are scarce. Grouse and Black game are diminishing. Population is nine adults and three school chidren. Eight dwellings in the area include the landlords home, three estate employees houses, two holiday cottages for tourism and a cottage. The community attend Skipness church, Claonaig Church being in dis-use.
